overview.name: Mario Games
overview.description: Mario characters appear in over 108 different games. Extremely popular with populations under 30 years old. Players download a saved game file, which functions as the primary text for the course. As they play through the game, they take notes on all major events, discoveries, and decisions.

overview.name: Smash Bros. Ultimate
overview.description: Super Smash Bros. is a competitive online game where players battle eachother as different characters from various Nintendo games.This source talks about large collection of players participating in a newly founded cultrue, E-sports.The emergent culture in this thesis is linked with the general professionalization of computer and console games. Sociologist T.L. Taylor documents this development in her book Raising the Stakes (2012), in which she conducts ethnographic research by following, interviewing, photographing and documenting various stakeholders, from players to organizers, during e-sport tournaments ranging from 2003 to 2011.13 Taylor describes a shift taking place within computer and console gaming. The e-sports scene is rapidly changing, because the nature of ‘gaming’ is itself

overview.name: Legend of Zelda
overview.description: The Legend of Zelda is an open world, puzzle based,RPG series.This source explains methods for automatic learning of design decisions from human authored levels. Human/computer interactions with in-game puzzles and RPG game-play. User experience while playing the game.

overview.name: Fan Bases
overview.description: These are fan run websites seperate from Nintendo. These websites spread user experience around the internet in relation to Nintendos games.

overview.name: Game Testing
overview.description: Beta Testers are real users that test games in production before their release. These users usually get paid to test these games and provide feedback to Nintendo based on their experience.

overview.name: Network
overview.description: Nintendo Network Servers have bases all across the globe. These Servers connect users from certain regional areas across the globe in order to play online and interact with eachother.

overview.name: E-Sports
overview.description: E-sports managament is based in Europe but Smash Bros. Ultimate Tournaments are managed in Japan. E-sports management ranges from event organizers, managers, community leaders and commentators. Smash Bros. Ultimate tournaments are associated with E-sports through an organization team in Europe.

overview.name: Fanbases
overview.description: There are 5 main Super Smash Bros. websites online where users interact with each other, Smashboards.com, Smashlabs.de, Reddit.com/r/smashbros, "Smash Ultimate Sverige: onlinekrigarnas discord" discord channel., "German Smash Com" German discord Server. Overall there are 330,300 members who participate within these websites sharing their experience.

overview.name: Game Design
overview.description: There are over 30,000 gaming programmers who work for nintendo. Most of these programmers work on game-design and codeing for all of Nintendo's various games. These programmers work to create the best experiences for users who purchase and play Nintendo's games. Many of Nintendo's games have complicated puzzles and platform levels that require skill. These programmers work to challenge users to navigate these puzzles and platform levels.

overview.name: Quality Control Program
overview.description: With Nintendo's philosophy stemming from quality control, they transferred this principle to merchandise. In New York, in October 1985, Nintendo launched a 150 staff team to quality check retail outlets in the north east.

sources.source: Statistic Paper: MITSUFUJI, Toshio, and Hidemi SHIMADA. "The Diffusion Process of the NINTENDO Entertainment System in the United States: 1985-1990." The Gakusen management review 7.1 (1993): 221-257.

overview.name: Quality Control Program
overview.description: The team of 150 paid employees traveled from retailer to retailer to analyze the quality of their products as well as understand the sale and direct-to-consumer process. They completed 7000 visits each month to ensure their products in this foreign country were as loved as in Japan.

sources.source: Statistic Paper: MITSUFUJI, Toshio, and Hidemi SHIMADA. "The Diffusion Process of the NINTENDO Entertainment System in the United States: 1985-1990." The Gakusen management review 7.1 (1993): 221-257.

overview.name: World of Nintendo Outlets
overview.description: After creating a business model which followed selling products directly to retailers than wholesalers, Nintendo gained more control over their products as well as a larger profit margin. This lead to the creation of 6000 "World of Nintendo" stores which provided "a complete line of products and licensed items" in the United States (27). The first store they made was in New York, followed by almost 6000 retailers providing Nintendo products, merchandise, and booths across the United States. In 2019 they finally opened an identical store in Japan.

overview.name: World of Nintendo Outlets
overview.description: After creating a business model which followed selling products directly to retailers than wholesalers, Nintendo gained more control over their products as well as a larger profit margin. This lead to the creation of 6000 "World of Nintendo" stores which provided "a complete line of products and licensed items" in the United States (27). The first store they made was in New York, followed by almost 6000 retailers providing Nintendo products, merchandise, and booths across the United States. In 2019 they finally opened an identical store in Japan.

overview.name: Game Play Counselors (Call Service)
overview.description: To supplement Nintendo's in-house game production, Nintendo USA created a toll-line in which both children and adults could call in to get information on their merchandising and gameplay accessories. This program remained active from 1987 to 2005, at its peak receiving 5000 calls per week. Not only did this create easy access to learn how to better play games, but the line also created significant merchandise and product quality management through constant feedback.

overview.name: Game Play Counselors (Call Service)
overview.description: In a continued source of merchandising and quality control, the Nintendo of America company (NOA) hired 33 full-time employees out of over 800 interviewed to be a source of information and product control in the US. This toll number enabled consumers to contact skilled players and informed employees to get special access to Nintendo services, merchandise, and games.

overview.name: Merchandise Review in Annual Report
overview.description: In Nintendo's fiscal year ending in March 2020, they reported annual merchandise revenue (game cards, clothing, etc.) of $28 million. While this only accounts for 0.23% of their overall income in that year, they did see a 57% increase in merchandise from the previous year.

overview.name: Pokemon Merchandise Effect
overview.description: A Stanford report compared and contrasted sales of Nintendo game units with the co-release of merchandise, movies, and accessories. In 1998, with the release of a new Pokemon game side-by-side with the Pokemon movie "Mewtwo Strikes Back" in Japanese theatres, they found a direct correlation. The co-release enhanced merchandise and game sales with an average increase of 3.3 million units sold.

sources.source: Report: Shinn, Gini. "Case Study: First Generation Pokèmon Games for the Nintendo Game Boy." Retrieved May 30 (2004): 2017. - https://web.stanford.edu/group/htgg/cgi-bin/drupal/sites/default/files2/gshin_2004_1.pdf

overview.name: Pokemon Merchandise Profitability
overview.description: Pokemon, one of the largest Nintendo brands, created $1.44 million of revenue across the US in 1999 when they partnered with local company 4Licensing Corporation to sell their intellectual property through merchandise. This brand's value vastly increased due to merchandising agreements in the US.

sources.source: News release and financial statement analysis in a report: "MmWire News Briefs -4Kids, EA, Loki Ent., NVIDIA, Sierra, Guillemot/Interplay Take-Two BDE/TLC Acclaim Ubi Soft Sierra." MMWire vol. 6 no. 104 1999 pp. 1. ProQuest https://colorado.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.colorado.idm.oclc.org/trade-journals/mmwire-news-briefs-4kids-ea-loki-ent-nvidia/docview/219597625/se-2?accountid=14503.

overview.name: Famikon Sales
overview.description: This product turned out to be a clever mix of product and merchandise. The extremely low initial cost of $87 led to excessive demand for Christmas 1985 in Japan which continued with constant store lines for this product until 1986. The mix of mostly a toy with a few tech integrations led this product to lead Nintendo sales.

sources.source: Reseach Paper: Igarashi, Fumio. "The Video Game with Media Potential." Japan Quarterly vol. 33 no. 3 1986, pp. 295. ProQuest https://colorado.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.colorado.idm.oclc.org/scholarly-journals/video-game-with-media-potential/docview/1304282616/se-2?accountid=14503.

overview.name: Activity-Based Accessories
overview.description: With the United States population percentage of citizens over 65 growing older, companies, government agencies, and individuals have started to emphasize the importance of health-based technology. Nintendo decided to capitalize on this trend by investing heavily into the activity-based production of Wii Sports (82.9 Million units sold) and Wii Fit (22.67 Million Units Sold) around the world.

sources.source: Correlation to Health: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Karen-Jacobs/publication/224052001_The_effect_of_the_Nintendo_Wii_Fit_and_exercise_in_improving_balance_and_quality_of_life_in_community_dwelling_elders/links/5551cced08ae739bdb923730/The-effect-of-the-Nintendo-Wii-Fit-and-exercise-in-improving-balance-and-quality-of-life-in-community-dwelling-elders.pdf, Boxing Game statistic: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3379718/
Keogh Justin WL et al. ""Physical and psychosocial function in residential aged-care elders: effect of Nintendo Wii Sports games."" Journal of aging and physical activity 22.2 (2014): 235-244."

overview.name: Founder
overview.description: Fusajiro Yamauchi is the founder and first president of Nintendo, born in Kyoto, Japan. He founded Nintendo Koppai as a trading card company in 1889 and opened the first "hanafuda" shop in Osaka, Japan.

overview.name: nintendo switch
overview.description: nintendo switch has sold over 78 million consoles worldwide. The switch has been considered one of the top gaming consoles in the gaming console market.

overview.name: wii
overview.description: the software unit sales for the Nintendo Wii and Nintendo Wii U between 2007 and 2020, Over 100 million units of software for the Nintendo Wii were sold in Nintendo's 2012 fiscal year. In the most recent period, the number has dropped to under one million. As of September 2020, it had sold 101.64 million units across the world, including over 33 million units in Europe.

overview.name: nintendo ds
overview.description: as of september 2020, nintendo has sold 154.9 million ds consoles globally including over 52 million in europe.
